On 7/25/07, B=E9k=E9si Tibor <bekesi2002@...> wrote:
> As far as I kn=
ow in JUnit 3 you could customize what to display in
> the JUnit view of Ec=
lipse by overriding the getName() method of the
> TestCase. Is there any si=
milar solution for that in JUnit 4?

A different set of design tradeoffs ma=
kes this difficult in JUnit 4.
in JUnit 3, you could ask each test case for=
 its name, but that
required having all of the test case obects instantiate=
d, which could
consume a lot of memory and start-up resources.  In JUnit 4,=
 the test
object does not exist until right before it runs, so it's up to a=

Runner to statically determine the name of each test.

By the way, this is=
 also the reason for the default naming in the
Parameterized runner.  We wa=
nted to be able to run on parameters that
were expensive to instantiate, or=
 could only be traversed once,
without reverting to the "all work up front"=
 model of JUnit 3.  So we
only check the size of the parameter list when th=
e methods are named.
It turns out that a lot of people are using lightweigh=
t parameters
like static String literals as their parameters, and, like you=
, have
no problem traversing the list multiple times.  This accounts for
pr=
etty much all the requests for renaming tests that I'm aware of.

> However=
, I would be interested in a solution that captures
> the "System.out" of m=
y "testMethod[1]" separately from
> the "System.out" of my "testMethod[2]".=


There is no built-in solution for this.  When possible, I try to
include =
as much information as possible in my assertion failures, so
that I don't h=
ave to look at System.out to debug.  When this isn't
possible, would it be =
enough to let each test know it's own name, so
you could print it to System=
.out?  If so, check out this posting:

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/j=
unit/message/18728

There should probably be a better way to do this in the=
 future, but
I'm not aware of a current feature request for it.  Thanks,

 =
  David Saff
